content:
Hi @T-compiler/meeting; the triage meeting will take place in about 2h
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and prepared the meeting agenda

We will have checkins from:

  • @WG-rfc-2229 checkin by @Matthew Jasper and @nikomatsakis : anything to share?
  • @WG-polymorphization checkin by @davidtwco : anything to share?
Hi @T-compiler/meeting , triage meeting starting now. Add a :wave: to show you’re here.

Lets start off with 8 minutes or so for

Announcements
• Tomorrow, at 09 AM 10 am EST, is the T-compiler planning meeting for the upcoming cycle
wait
no
@apiraino is this not recorded correctly in the compiler-team calendar or sometbin?
(working on 2229 update now, give me 5 mins)
I’ll look into this after the meeting.

• New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • "A --temps-dir option for specifying where the intermediate files are written" compiler-team#423

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "Debuggable Macro Expansions" compiler-team#386
    • "Staged queries" compiler-team#391
    • "Do not traverse the HIR to generate metadata" compiler-team#392
    • "Embed version numbers in backport nominations and regression labels" compiler-team#393
    • "Add different entry points for x.py" compiler-team#396
    • "rustdoc is using rustc_ast_pretty, would it be possible to make it somewhat "stable"?" compiler-team#403
    • "Eagerly construct bodies of THIR" compiler-team#409
    • "LLVM plugin support in Rust" compiler-team#419
    • "Rename -Cllvm-args to something backend agnostic" compiler-team#421

• Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • No pending FCP requests this time.

• Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "MCP: More Cranelift-friendly portable SIMD intrinsics" compiler-team#381
    • "Uplift the invalid_atomic_ordering lint from clippy to rustc" compiler-team#390
    • "Lang Item for Transmutability" compiler-team#411
    • "Switch JSON serialization from rustc_serialize to serde" compiler-team#418
    • "Lint large assignments and locals" compiler-team#420
    • "Update the existing musl targets to be dynamically linked." compiler-team#422

• Accepted MCPs
    • "Filter out query machinery from compiler backtraces by default" compiler-team#410

• Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • "Allow qualified paths in struct construction (both expressions and patterns)" rust#80080
    • "Stabilize cmp_min_max_by" rust#81047
    • "Adding diesel to the cargotest suite" rust#81507
    • "Stabilize peekable_peek_mut" rust#81938
    • "reduce threads spawned by ui-tests" rust#81942
    • "Add strong_count mutation methods to Rc" rust#83476

@WG-polymorphization checkin by @davidtwco:

There's nothing to report from the polymorphization working group.

Aman Arora said:

(working on 2229 update now, give me 5 mins)

We can circle back around to this at the end of the meeting, no problem.

• Feature mostly works and is avaiable under #![feature(capture_disjoint_fields)]
  • We have handled all edge cases we are aware of including patterns, FRU syntax, references in move closures, handling unsafe
  • Migration lint for drop reordering is supported under #[deny(disjoint_capture_drop_reorder)] and is supported using rust fix.
  • On going work to support migration for auto-traits, and diagnostics
oh there we go. :)
No, its here :stuck_out_tongue:

Aman Arora said:

  • Feature mostly works and is avaiable under #![feature(capture_disjoint_fields)]
  • We have handled all edge cases we are aware of including patterns, FRU syntax, references in move closures, handling unsafe
  • Migration lint for drop reordering is supported under #[deny(disjoint_capture_drop_reorder)] and is supported using rust fix.
  • On going work to support migration for auto-traits, and diagnostics

this is awesome :D
this is like the number one papercut I run into with the borrowchecker
one more announcement
I don’t know if you all saw, but Niko is stepping back from his role on the core team.
which of course means that all the bugs in traits and type system in general will soon be fixed.
(:laughing:)
but seriously, just want to take a moment and give a :clap: for all the time and effort Niko spent on core
okay moving on
Backport nominations

T-compiler stable / T-compiler beta

  • No backport nominations for T-compiler this time.

T-libs-impl stable / T-libs-impl beta

  • No backport nominations for T-libs-impl this time.

T-rustdoc stable / T-rustdoc beta

  • "Fix Self keyword doc URL conflict on case insensitive file systems (until definitely fixed on rustdoc)" rust#83678
    • opened by @GuillaumeGomez
    • approved by @Joshua Nelson
    • Fixes #80504 and prevents #83154 and related rust-lang/rustup#2694
    • mentioned last week -> postponed backport decision after checking if patch actually fixes the issue (@Joshua Nelson confirms PR fixes the issue)
is this bug a beta regression?
it's a stable regression, it first broke in 1.50
ah
but we’re not stable nominating it?
well the impact is limited https://github.com/rust-lang/rustup/issues/2694
it only affects installing linux docs on mac or windows
okay
I don't have any opposition to a stable backport though, it's a simple fix
it seems fine
I guess
its a (self-described) hack
oh definitely
but doing this "properly" breaks the whole ecosystem
right

there's like 3 hours of arguing about this in https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/266220-rustdoc/topic/Case.20insensitive.20RFC.20take.20two and https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/266220-rustdoc/topic/case.20insensitive.20RFC.20rust-lang.2Frfcs.233097
heh
feel free to link to the specific topic! :lol:
anyway if the rustdoc team in general is okay with a beta backport here, then I think we can backport approve. Its early enough in the cycle that hopefully we can revert it if we discover a need.
backport approved.
• No stable nominations for T-rustdoc this time.
FWIW I see this as low-risk - it just makes the URL look uglier

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

• "add dynamically-linked musl targets" rust#82556
    • actionables from the meeting
      • Written an MCP, verify whether we can give warnings, and have the team sign it off
      • Finally a blog post to give a heads up and guidance comment
      • mentioned last week: give feedback to author before closing the issue and move on
I looked and just realized that rust#82556 didn’t have links to the design meeting nor the MCP. Added a comment with those.

but other than that, I don’t think we have anything we need to do right now on this. Its still too soon to close rust#82556; I think we should only do that after 1. the MCP comment period is finished, and (potentaily) 2. we have a blog post explaining the shift.

T-libs-impl

  • No PRs waiting on T-libs-impl this time.

Issues of Note

Short Summary

  • 0 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 0 of those are unassigned
  • 63 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 39 of those are unassigned
  • 0 P-critical, 2 P-high, 4 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
  • 1 P-critical, 1 P-high, 4 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
  • 0 P-critical, 38 P-high, 88 P-medium, 10 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable

P-critical

T-compiler

  • No P-critical issues for T-compiler this time.

T-libs-impl

  • No P-critical issues for T-libs-impl this time.

T-rustdoc

  • No P-critical issues for T-rustdoc this time.

P-high regressions

P-high beta regressions

• "probe-stack=inline-asm generates wrong DWARF information" rust#83139
    • partially mitigated by @pnkfelix in PR #82412, which reverts PR #77885
    • from the PR comment: after we resolve #83139 (potentially by backporting a fix to LLVM or by deciding that one cannot rely on the quality of our DWARF output in the manner described in #83139), we can change this back
last week, I believe we saw evidence that there was active work/discussion on the LLVM code review about the approach(es) here.
upstream LLVM bug: https://bugs.llvm.org/show_bug.cgi?id=49600
hmm but I’m not sure if there’s been work on it since March 30th
@nagisa do you have any insight here? Do you think YangKeao is going to continue working on it?
(if not, then we may need to switch gears to evaluating whether we will fix this on our own, or let it break.)
/me reads
So, one part of this has already landed upstream.
oh really?
I didn’t see that in the links I was looking at
which only concerns the "unrolled" version of the probes.
(those happen until approximately 8 pages)
https://reviews.llvm.org/D99579 is what landed.
we _could_ backport that and resolve a large majority of cases where this occurs.
so you are saying that https://bugs.llvm.org/show_bug.cgi?id=49600 describes two cases: rolled non-unrolled, and unrolled?
and only the unrolled case is addressed
Right, LLVM will still generate invalid uwtables in situations where LLVM decides to generate a loop to probe the stack.
i see
I think I’d be in favor of the backport. A partial solution is better than nothing, right?
There's a https://reviews.llvm.org/D99585 for fixing the loop case but that solution isn't as obviously correct or best.
(I know arguments that one can pose, saying that landiing a partial solution means effort won’t be invested in the complete solution.)
okay
I think I’m okay with letting development here proceed as its going
and looking into a backport of https://reviews.llvm.org/D99579
Yeah I think it makes sense to backport.
i’ll add a link
sorry that we haven't been posting the updates on the issue ourselves :frown:
(I totally forgot, myself)
not a problem
as long as we track them down eventually
look at it this way: it makes me feel like the triage meeting has value. :)
next up

Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

  • No unassigned P-high nightly regressions this time.

Performance logs

2021-04-06 Full triage logs

A pretty major week for memory usage improvements, while wall time performance
largely stayed neutral, with an average of ~20% gains on memory usage for
release builds, and 5% on check builds, due to an update in the default allocator
used (to a more recent jemalloc).

Triage done by @simulacrum: 1 Regressions, 4 Improvements, 0 Mixed
:party_ball:

Regressions

add OR_PATTERNS_BACK_COMPAT lint #83468

  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 1.2% on incr-patched: println builds of coercions-debug)
  • Relatively small hit on a number of benchmarks. Likely largely unavoidable.

Improvements

  • Stream the dep-graph to a file instead of storing it in-memory #82780
  • panic early when TrustedLen indicates a length > usize::MAX #83726
  • Use tikv-jemallocator in rustc/rustdoc in addition to jemalloc-sys when enabled. #83152

Nags requiring follow up

  • The issue from three weeks ago has stalled.
    Likely this needs someone to mentor the author, or to take over the
    investigation.
the author filed this issue with rustc-perf: https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-perf/issues/854
Hey @Wesley Wiser I need to go AFK for a moment
I was going to ask if anyone wants to volunteer to mentor here
but otherwise lets leave the nag open

Nominated Issues

T-compiler
(really, what I want here is a Status Quo story for their experience trying to profile rustc.)

• "undefined reference to linker error when using dylibs" rust#82151
    • (postponed from previous meeting)
(yeah I haven’t had much time to investigate rust#82151. its still on my list)
It doesn't look like there's been any movement on the issue since the last meeting.
Ok.
(I’m hoping to spend time on it today or tomorrow)
(okay really going AFK now)
We'll move on then

• "add dynamically-linked musl targets" rust#82556
    • (see item in S-waiting-on-team)
We've talked about this a bit already in this meeting.
Let's wait until the FCP period completes and then the next step will be to write the blog post.

• "Add default search path to Target::search()" rust#83800
    • I-nominated by @nagisa: see comment

Nominating for a brief look at the T-compiler meeting. It isn't entirely obvious to me if we are comfortable with enable further ability to transparently use adhoc target json specs given how unstable they are in practice.

OTOH fetching them from sysroot sounds like a pretty good middle-ground here.
The patch seems pretty straightforward to me but I do wonder if this is the sort of change that falls under the MCP process?
Looks like we don't even have an open issue asking for this functionality.
Which increases my feeling we should MCP this to make sure this is the design we want before shipping it.
I will leave a comment on this PR to that effect.
Yeah, or I might even.. want an RFC?
Like, this is pretty clearly user-visible surface area, and at least somewhat stable
Maybe a short RFC, but it feels like it's worth doing that analysis

Perhaps? Yeah.

I believe the MCP process does allow for stabilization of certain kinds of compiler options but with a FCP checkoff? I will have to go back and review.
Yeah, I mean, I mostly want the answers to the background research / prior art section here :)
I will take an action item to figure out if an MCP or RFC is appropriate and then leave a comment on the PR.

T-libs-impl

  • No nominated issues for T-libs-impl this time.

RFC

  • No nominated RFCs for T-compiler this time.
and that's the meeting agenda!
Since we are quite early, I will give a minute for anyone to bring up anything they feel needs to be discussed today. Otherwise we can wrap up early

pnkfelix said:

(really, what I want here is a Status Quo story for their experience trying to profile rustc.)

my first impression is "bad" because I never do it locally, but I don't know if that's just because I have the impression it's hard or because it's actually hard
trying to replicate https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-perf/issues/854 so I can give more useful feedback
No such file or directory (os error 2)
Ouch
yeah perf runs into lots of weird errors like that
the error messages are not great
Yeah, I've been working on a Windows port and run into similar issues.
The most obvious thing that comes to mind is that perhaps cachegrind is not installed or not on their path for some reason.
Well, it's not the only message in this case. It looks like a cargo pkgid failure
Sounds like MCP material to me
wow #16351 is old
#83800?
I think we can continue this conversation outside this meeting if necessary.
sorry, yes, my zulip hadn’t refreshed
Thanks everyone for attending! Have a great morning/afternoon/evening :wave:
Thanks @Wesley Wiser for taking over at last minute

Draft for next week's agenda:
https://hackmd.io/8vxPKnHtRqm481lSI5WmqQ?view

Scheduled checkins:

  • @WG-rls2.0 checkin by @matklad
  • @WG-self-profile checkin by @Wesley Wiser and michaelwoerister
This topic was moved by simulacrum to #t-compiler > target.json search path
